Enhanced fischer-tropsch synthesis performance on Co@SiO2 catalyst with core-shell structure Mengyao Yun Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Investigation Data curation Tao Chen Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Investigation Data curation Conceptualization Ning Zhao Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Investigation Data curation Zhenhua Li Writing – review & editing Validation Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China Key Lab for Green Chemical Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300350, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Energy is of great importance for the development of modern society, which is mostly dependent on crude oil. Due to the severe pollution caused by using crude oil and the diminishing of crude oil reserves, it is urgent to look for clean oil from alternative resource other than crude oil. Currently, Coal-to-Liquid (CTL) or Biomass-to-Liquid (BTL) technology is an important way to produce clean liquid fuels through Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) of syngas. For FTS process, catalyst is a main factor for affecting on syngas conversion and product distribution. For traditional oxides-supported catalysts, the mutual constraint between active metal loading and dispersion at high metal loading is hard to overcome, which will hinder the synthesis of high-performance FTS catalysts. In this paper, a new type of Co@SiO2-T (CS-T) and Co@SiO2-X (CS-X) catalysts with core-shell structure were prepared by using polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) as the structural stabilizer, hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium Bromide (CTAB) as the templating agent and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silica source. The effects of hydrothermal temperature and pyrolysis temperature on the catalyst physical-chemical properties and FTS performance were investigated. The results showed that increasing the hydrothermal temperature favored the formation of the core-shell structure of the catalysts. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the catalyst particle size decreased from 0.54 μm to 0.23 μm. The FTS activities of the catalysts showed a volcano trend with hydrothermal and pyrolysis temperatures. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fischer-tropsch synthesis Cobalt-based catalyst Silica Core-shell structure Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Syngas is a kind of feedstock gas with H2 and CO as main components, which can be converted into various hydrocarbon fuels and high value-added chemicals through FTS [1,2]. FTS reaction is one of the key links to achieve clean utilization of coal and other carbon-containing resources and ensure the security of the national energy strategy [3,4]. In 1925, the German scientists Frans Fischer and Hans Tropsch firstly put forward the process theory of FTS. FTS refers to the chain polymerization reaction of syngas (H2 + CO) catalyzed by catalyst conversion to produce hydrocarbons with different carbon numbers at a certain temperature and pressure [5–7], the main reaction process is as follows: (1.1) ( 2 n + 1 ) H 2 + n CO → C n H 2 n + 2 + n H 2 O (1.2) 2 n H 2 + n CO → C n H 2 n + n H 2 O (1.3) 2 n H 2 + n CO → C n H 2 n + 2 O + ( n − 1 ) H 2 O (1.4) H 2 O + CO → C O 2 + H 2 The FTS route is intricate with the product carbon chain exhibiting a wide distribution including alkanes, olefins and oxygenated compounds. The wide distribution of products significantly impacts the industrial production cost. Researchers concluded that the FTS product selectivity adheres to the Anderson- Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution (Fig. 1.1 ). With the exception of the C1 product, all products characterized by different carbon chain numbers have selectivity limits. Specifically, the selectivity limits are 58 % for low carbon hydrocarbons (C2∼C4), 45 % for gasoline fraction (C5∼C11) and 30 % for diesel fraction (C12∼C20) [8–11]. Cobalt and iron catalysts are the primary types of industrial catalysts used in FTS technology [12,13]. Fe-based catalysts are predominantly employed in the production of low carbon olefins, owing to their low metal activity, the need for higher reaction temperatures and high water gas shift (WGS) activity [14,15]. Co-based catalysts are suitable for low-temperature FTS and are the best choice for the synthesis of long-chain hydrocarbons due to high resistance to deactivation, low WGS reactivity, high conversion and high hydrocarbon yields [16,17]. The dispersion of cobalt and cobalt oxides is one of the key factors determining their catalytic performance [18,19]. Meanwhile, the carrier effect of Co-based catalysts is notably obvious, the carrier serves to furnish a high specific surface area, facilitating the dispersion of active components. This enhancement not only bolsters sintering resistance but also augments mass transfer and diffusion rates of both reactants and products [20–22], while stabilizing the active phases. Consequently, the selection of appropriate carrier materials is of paramount importance. There are three main types of FTS catalyst carriers: metal oxides [22–25], carbon nanomaterials [26,27] and molecular sieves [28–30]. SiO2 is a widely utilized carrier for cobalt-based catalysts in FTS, where its structure notably influences catalyst performance [31–33]. The abundance of silica hydroxyl (-OH) groups on the surface of SiO2 carriers have a significant effect on the hydrophobic and diffusive properties of the catalysts, which is capable of modulating the distribution of FTS products [34,35]. Pei et al. [36] introduced tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as a silica precursor for the modification of the commercial activated carbon (AC) carriers to inhibit the aggregation of cobalt particles and improve reaction activity. The moderate amount of SiO2 promoted the generation of Co2C and enhanced the selectivity of high-carbon alcohols (C6∼C18) in the products. In addition, SiO2 exhibits a weak interaction with the metal, which is conducive to the dispersion and reduction of the active metal. Yaghoobpour et al. [37] introduced SiO2 into the γ-Al2O3 carrier, resulting in catalysts that exhibited robust FTS activity with reduced cobalt particle size and enhanced reducibility. The common core-shell structure catalysts for FTS reactions consist of a metal core and a molecular sieve shell structure, which is a special type of supported catalysts. Syngas molecules traverse the molecular sieve pores to reach the core, where CO hydrogenation occurs to generate hydrocarbons. Simultaneously, acid catalyzed reactions take place as the molecules diffuse within the molecular sieve pores. Typically, this type of catalyst demonstrates excellent thermal stability. Javed et al. [38] synthesized a series of molecular sieve co-embedded cobalt-based catalysts through hydrothermal synthesis using a simple solvent-free milling route (Fig. 1.2 ). It was shown that the acidity of the molecular sieves affects the distribution of FTS products. As Silica-1 was the least acidic, it was more favorable for the cleavage of long-chain hydrocarbons into gasoline segment fractions. In contrast, HZSM-5 with stronger Brønsted acid sites led to excessive cleavage of the carbon chains, which shifted the products towards lower carbon hydrocarbons. The weaker acid sites and open porous structure on the surface and in the pores of Co@S-1 catalysts enhanced the selectivity of the gasoline segment fractions. Meanwhile, the hydrophobicity of Silica-1 inhibited the WGS reaction and reduced the generation of CO2 as a by-product. Zhu et al. [39] enhanced the selectivity of Co-Al2O3 matrix catalyst for gasoline products by coating it with a ZSM-5 membrane of adjustable thickness. During the reaction, the Al2O3 matrix provided efficient mass and heat transfer structure, while the ZSM-5 membrane layer acted as a hydrocarbon cleavage and isomerization agent, which synergistically resulted in a catalyst CO conversion of 78.7 % and a gasoline selectivity as high as 93.3 % in a 75 % C5+ oil. Liu et al. [40] used a conventional Co/SiO2 catalyst as the precursor, utilizing the gradual dissolution of silica during the hydrothermal process as the silica source and the structure-directing agent TPAOH to introduce Al into the zeolite framework. During the synthesis, Co3O4 clusters from the original catalyst were encapsulated in HZSM-5 crystals, ensuring the dispersion of the cobalt active sites and promoting hydrocracking and isomerization reactions on the HZSM-5 acid sites. Lin et al. [41] prepared Co-Pd/SiO2 capsule catalysts (Co‐Pd/SiO2@H‐ZSM‐5) by hydrothermal method. The results showed that the presence of Pd could inhibit the formation of cobalt silicate, thereby promoting the reduction of CoO and enhancing the selectivity of this catalyst for isoparaffins in gasoline fraction C5∼C11 with niso/nn as high as 1.03. In this paper, a series of cobalt-based catalysts were synthesized using the hydrothermal method, starting from the core-shell structure of cobalt FTS catalysts. The morphology and structure of the catalysts were adjusted by changing the hydrothermal and pyrolysis temperatures during the synthesis process respectively. The impact of these temperature variations on the catalyst's activity and product selectivity was examined, aiming to develop cobalt-based FTS catalysts with high activity, selectivity for gasoline range (C5∼C11) products and stability, while also identifying the optimal preparation conditions for the Co@SiO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 98.5 wt%), ammonia (NH3·H2O, 25.0∼28.0 wt%), sodium hydroxide (NAOH, analytical pure) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, average molecular weight > 8000) were purchased from Kermel Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Ethanol (C2H5OH, analytical pure) was purchased from Jiangtian Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). Hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium Bromide (CTAB, 99.0 wt%) was purchased from Aladdin Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98.0 wt%) was purchased from Komeier Co., Ltd. (Tianjin, China). 2.2 Synthesis of Co@SiO2-T The preparation procedure for the CS-T catalysts involved the following steps: 3.5 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 1.77 g of PVP were dissolved in 50 mL of anhydrous ethanol and stirred at room temperature for 30 min to obtain a reddish brown solution. The above solution was transferred to a 100 mL crystallization kettle and crystallized at T °C (T = 140, 160, 180, 200) for 4 h. Post-crystallization, the mixture was cooled to room temperature and the suspension was further processed by adding 100 mL deionized water, 125 mL ethanol and 1.25 g CTAB, followed by stirring. Subsequently, 3 mL of ammonia (25 wt%) was added dropwise. After 1 hour stirring at room temperature, 3 mL of TEOS was slowly added dropwise and then kept stirring for an additional 24 h at room temperature. Then, the solution was separated by centrifugation (8500 rmp, 5 min) three times through a mixture of ethanol and water at a volume ratio of 1:1. The precipitated product was then collected. The resulting precipitate was placed in a desiccator and dried at 80 °C overnight. The dried product was placed in a quartz boat and heated in a tube furnace under argon atmosphere at 3 °C/min to 600 °C, then being kept at 600 °C for 3 h. The final samples were named as CS-T (T = 140, 160, 180, 200 °C) catalysts. The synthesis route of CS-T catalysts is shown in Fig. 2.1 . 2.3 Synthesis of Co@SiO2-X The CS-X catalysts were synthesized as follows: the hydrothermal temperature was 180 °C, the pyrolysis temperature was heated to X °C (X = 400, 500, 600, 700) by 3 °C/min, and the rest of the steps were the same as those for the preparation of CS-T catalysts in Section 2.2. The prepared samples were named as CS-X catalysts. The route for synthesis of CS-X catalysts is shown in Fig. 2.2 . 2.4 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) tests were conducted on the samples using a Rigaku Smartlab 9 kW diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode and a Hypix 3000 detector. Cu/Kα radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm) was employed as the source of radiation, with diffraction angles ranging from 20° to 80° in increments of 10°/min. The operating current was set at 200 mA and the operating voltage was 40 kV. These tests were performed to analyze the crystal structure of the samples, identify the type of cobalt species present and calculate the cobalt grain size. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) tests were carried out on the samples using a field emission scanning electron microscope model S8100 of Hitachi to analyze the surface morphology of each sample. The accelerating voltage of the test was 0.5∼30 kV. The specific sampling process was as follows: firstly, a small amount of powdered sample was dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and sonicated for 30 min. Secondly, the upper layer of the suspension was added dropwise to a copper sheet using a capillary tube and then the drops were repeated for 4∼6 drops after drying. Finally, the copper sheet was fixed on the sample stage by means of conductive adhesive and sprayed with gold using ion sputtering apparatus. The samples were subjected to transmission electron microscopy and energy spectroscopy tests using a JEOL-F2100 transmission electron microscope (TEM) from Japan Electronics. This device can be used to analyze the bulk structure characteristics such as element distribution, microstructure and metal particle size. The TEM operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The sample preparation involved dispersing a small amount of powdered sample in anhydrous ethanol, followed by 30 min of sonication. The upper layer of the suspension was then transferred to an ultrathin carbon film using a capillary tube, with 4–6 drops applied after drying. The physical structure and texture characteristics of the samples were investigated using TriStar 3000 and 3Flex Physical Adsorption Instrument from Micromeritics, USA. The test procedure was as follows: before the test, 0.1–0.12 g of sample was weighed into the sample tube, nitrogen was introduced into the tube and the sample was pre-treated at 300 °C for 4 h to remove water and other impurities from the sample. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore size distribution of the samples was calculated by BJH method and NFDLT method. The samples were subjected to hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction tests to determine the reduction temperature of each species in the catalyst using an AutoChem 2910 instrument from Micromeritics, USA. The procedure was as follows: weighing about 50 mg of samples in a U-tube, purging in argon at 200 °C for 1 hour to remove impurities, cooling down to 50 °C and then switching to 10 % H2 /Ar gas to raise the temperature to 780 °C (10 °C/min). The hydrogen consumption signal during the warming process was recorded by a TCD detector. The number of active sites in the catalysts was determined through a hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption test using the AutoChem 2910 instrument from Micromeritics in the United States. The specific test procedure was as follows: 50 mg samples was put in a U-tube and reduced by flowing H2 at 400 °C for 2 h, the gas was switched to argon for continuous purging to a temperature of 50 °C after reduction. Subsequently, the gas was switched to 10 % H2/Ar gas and the adsorption was carried out at low temperatures for 1 h Then, the gas was switched to argon again. After the TCD signal was stable, the sample was heated to 400 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and kept at 400 °C for 2 h The signal recorded by the TCD detector provided the H2-TPD test results for the samples. 2.5 FTS performance test The FTS performance test flowchart is shown in Fig. 2.3 . The specific FTS reaction evaluation process was as follows: firstly, 0.4 g of 40–60 mesh catalyst and 2.5 g of 40–60 mesh quartz sand were homogeneously mixed and loaded into a stainless steel reactor tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm. Subsequently, argon gas was introduced into the reactor and pressurized to 2.4 MPa for 1 hour to conduct a leak test. After the pressure was relieved to atmospheric pressure, the catalyst was reduced under H2 atmosphere at 400 °C for 10 h (GHSV = 7.5 SL/(h·g)). After the reduction was completed and the bed temperature was reduced to below 100 °C, syngas (VH2/VCO/VAr=6:3:1) was introduced and the bed temperature was slowly warmed up to 230 °C. The reaction pressure and airspeed were 2 MPa and 7.5 SL/(h·g) respectively. After the reaction stabilized, the non-condensable gas and low carbon hydrocarbon products were analyzed online by Agilent 6820 GC gas chromatography equipped with a thermal conductivity cell detector (TCD) and a flame ionization detector (FID) (High-purity He was used as the carrier gas). The oil and wax products from were collected by a cold trap (−4 °C) and a hot trap (170 °C) respectively. The cold and hot trap products were quantitatively analyzed offline using a SP-3420 GC equipped with a Flame Ionization Detector (FID) (N2 was used as the carrier gas) for calculating the C5+ product distribution. The water in the cold and hot trap products should be separated before off-line analysis. The cold trap products can be used for chromatographic analysis directly after removing the water, while the hot trap products need to be dissolved with an appropriate amount of CS2 before chromatographic analysis. CO conversion and selectivity are obtained by the following formula (2–1)∼(2–5): (2.1) X CO ( % ) = CO ( in , mol ) − CO ( out , mol ) CO ( in , mol ) × 100 (2.2) S C H 4 ( % ) = C H 4 ( out , mol ) CO ( in , mol ) − CO ( out , mol ) − C O 2 ( out , mol ) × 100 (2.3) S C O 2 ( % ) = C O 2 ( out , mol ) CO ( in , mol ) − CO ( out , mol ) × 100 (2.4) S C n ( % , n = 2 , 3 , 4 ) = n × C n ( out , mol ) CO ( in , mol ) − CO ( out , mol ) − C O 2 ( out , mol ) × 100 (2.5) S C 5 + ( % ) = 100 − S C H 4 − S C 2 − S C 3 − S C 4 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Co@SiO2-T catalyst characterization To explore the effect of hydrothermal temperature on the formation of cobalt core in CS-T catalysts, TEM characterization was carried out. As can be seen in Fig. 3.1 , the core layer part in CS-140 and CS-160 catalysts did not form a complete spherical structure and the cobalt species tended to aggregate. These incomplete cobalt cores had a low adsorption capacity to the templating agent CTA+ micelles and could not form a complete core-shell structure [42]. With the further increase of hydrothermal temperature, the core layer portion in CS-180 and CS-200 catalysts was more complete. The cobalt species were well dispersed, showing a good core-shell structure. TEM images show that the particle size of cobalt particles in CS-T catalysts decreased from 17.7 nm to 10.7 nm with the increase of hydrothermal temperature, indicating that the increase of hydrothermal temperature not only promote the formation of cobalt core, but also improve the dispersion of cobalt particles. Further observation of Fig. 3.1-d reveals that a certain amount of SiO2 spheres appeared around the CS-200 catalyst. As reported [43], PVP was adsorbed onto the surface of cobalt particles through hydrogen bonding and formed spherical particles during the hydrothermal process. The stable cobalt particles on PVP were conducive to the uniform growth of SiO2 shell due to the interaction between PVP and Si-OH groups, making SiO2 shell formed on the cobalt core sphere. At high hydrothermal temperature, the interaction between PVP and cobalt species is stronger and interaction between PVP and Si-OH groups is weakened, resulting in some Si-OH groups failing to participate in the formation of the shell and instead aggregating into SiO2 spheres. According to the results of lattice fringes in the HRTEM images, we found that cobalt species existed in CoO after being pyrolyzed at low temperatures, while cobalt species existed in Co3O4 after being pyrolyzed at high temperatures. Fig. 3.2 and Table 3.1 show the results of N2 physical adsorption and desorption tests of CS-T catalysts. As can be seen from Fig. 3.2-a, all catalysts exhibited type IV adsorption- desorption isothermal with H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures in the CS-T catalysts. These mesoporous structures can be attributed to the continuous decomposition of CTAB in the SiO2 shell layer during the pyrolysis process. The results of the pore size distribution of CS-T catalysts in Fig. 3.2-b indicate that the samples showed obvious pore stacking at approximately 2.0 nm and 4.0 nm, proving that the CS-T catalysts had mesoporous structures. As can be seen from Table 3.1, the specific surface area of the samples gradually decreased with the increase of hydrothermal temperature. Fig. 3.3 shows the XRD results of the CS-T catalysts, which shows that cobalt species existed in the form of oxides in the CS-T, being consistent with HRTEM result. The cobalt oxide size was obtained using Scherrer equation and the results are listed in Table 3.1. Fig. 3.4 -a indicates the H2-TPR results of the CS-T catalysts. It can be seen that all catalysts showed the reduction process of two-step reduction of Co3O4 species. The hydrogen consumption peak at lower temperatures can be attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, while the hydrogen consumption peak at higher temperatures can be attributed to the reduction of CoO to Co0. Among them, the XRD of the CS-140 catalyst indicated that the cobalt species existed in the form of CoO, which was gradually oxidized to Co3O4 by air. It was observed that the temperature of the reduction hydrogen consumption peak of the Co3O4 species for the CS-T catalysts followed a tendency to increase and then decrease. This can be attributed to the fact that when the hydrothermal temperature was lower than 160 °C, the complete spherical cobalt core could not be formed during the hydrothermal process. The cobalt particles appeared to be agglomerated since the interaction of cobalt particles with the shell layer SiO2 species was weak. When the hydrothermal temperature was increased to 180 °C, the catalyst formed regular cobalt core. The cobalt species had strong metal-carrier interactions with SiO2 and the reduction temperature of the cobalt species increased. As the hydrothermal temperature further increased, the interaction between the structural stabilizer PVP and cobalt species enhanced, the complexation ability of cobalt core to the SiO2 shell layer reduced, the metal-carrier interaction weakened, and the reduction temperature of cobalt species decreased. In addition, the reduction peaks of CS-180 and CS-200 catalysts at 550∼650 °C and over 650 °C can be attributed to the gasification peaks of the carbon species in the catalysts and the reduction from Co3+ to Co2+ in the cobalt spinel species respectively. The H2-TPD results of CS-T catalysts are shown in Fig. 3.4-b and Table 3.2 . The fitting results of the H2-TPD revealed that all the CS-T catalysts exhibited three kinds of different adsorption strengths of hydrogen, namely weak interaction adsorption hydrogen with a desorption temperature below 144 °C, moderate interaction adsorption hydrogen with a desorption temperature between 196 and 225 °C and strong interaction adsorption hydrogen with a desorption temperature above 400 °C. Due to the low reaction temperature (230 °C), it is difficult for this part of hydrogen to desorb from the active sites during the reaction process, so the strong hydrogen adsorption sites were not counted in the calculation of the number of cobalt active sites. By calculating the desorption amounts of weakly and moderately interacting adsorbed hydrogen, we found that the amount of hydrogen adsorbed on the CS-T increased and then decreased with the increase of hydrothermal temperature, indicating that the number of cobalt active sites in the catalysts increased and then decreased. 3.2 FTS performance of Co@SiO2-T catalyst The above characterization results indicate that increasing hydrothermal temperature is beneficial for the formation of the core layer and the dispersion of cobalt species. To further probe the impact of hydrothermal temperature on catalytic performance, FTS evaluation was conducted and shown in Fig. 3.5 and Table 3.3 . The results suggest that variations in hydrothermal temperature lead to an initial increase and subsequent decrease in the FTS activity of the CS-T catalysts. Among them, the CS-180 catalyst exhibited good reactivity and stability due to its regular core-shell structure and strong metal-carrier interactions between cobalt species and silica. In addition, the introduction of inert carbon in the PVP improved the surface hydrophobicity of the mesoporous pores, which helped to remove the water generated during the reaction process and reduces the number of cobalt active sites occupied by adsorbed water, increasing the reactivity [44]. Therefore, based on the protection of the porous silica shell, the CS-180 catalyst maintained a high dispersion of cobalt species and the highest number of active sites, with more active sites available for CO hydrogenation, exhibiting the highest CO conversion of 77.2 %, which is significantly higher than the other three catalysts. It was concluded that at hydrothermal temperature below 160 °C, the SiO2 shell layer derived from TEOS hydrolysis failed to play a good domain-limiting role due to the failure of the core layer to form a regular spherical morphology, resulting in an aggregation of cobalt particles, which lowered the CO conversion rates of the CS-140 and CS-160 catalysts. In the case of the CS-200 catalyst, the high hydrothermal temperature led to a reduced ability of the cobalt cores to form complexation with Si-OH groups, the Si-OH groups not complexed to the catalyst shell layer were dispersed around the catalyst to form SiO2 spheres, which clogged the catalyst pores and inhibited the further occurrence of the reaction, resulting in a decrease in the CO conversion rate of the catalyst. With the increase of hydrothermal temperature, C5∼C11 fraction increased first and then decreased a little. Hydrocarbon selectivity is related to intraparticle diffusion in the catalyst, α-olefin reabsorption and chain-induced interactions [42]. Among the CS-T catalysts, the CS-180 exhibited the highest C5∼C11 fraction as 78.4 %, which was attributed to the carbon-modified hydrophobic pores in the CS-180 catalyst that limited product diffusion and increased the chances of reabsorption of intermediates such as α-olefins, which lead to the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons [45]. Meanwhile, the abundant mesopores in the CS-180 catalyst played a spatially restrictive role in the mass transfer process, inhibiting the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons. The synergistic effect to these factors made the product distribution concentrated towards the middle fraction, showing good product selectivity in the C5∼C11 fraction for the CS-180 catalyst; Agglomeration of cobalt species in CS-140 and CS-160 catalysts, incomplete cobalt cores with low adsorption capacity to the templating agent CTA+ micelles, which could not form a complete core-shell structure and lost the role of spatial restriction effect of the core-shell structure, resulting in low gasoline fraction selectivity of 32.1 % and 40.3 % respectively; CS-200 catalyst also showed good C5∼C11 fraction selectivity of 60.2 % due to the spatial restriction effect of the core-shell structure and the inert carbon modified mesoporous pore, but the C5∼C11 fraction selectivity was lower than that of CS-180 catalyst owing to the influence of the surrounding SiO2 spheres. 3.3 Co@SiO2-X catalyst characterization The textural properties of the CS-X catalysts were characterized using N2 physisorption and the results are presented in Fig. 3.6 and Table 3.4 . Fig. 3.6-a illustrates that all catalysts exhibited type IV adsorption-desorption isothermal and H3-type hysteresis loops, which are typical of mesoporous materials. The formation of mesopores can be attributed to the removal of templating agent CTAB during pyrolysis. Fig. 3.6-b expresses the results of the pore size distribution of CS-X catalysts. All the samples displayed obvious pore stacking at 4.0 nm, indicating that the CS-X catalysts had mesoporous structure. In addition, except for the CS-600 catalyst, the other catalysts demonstrated pore stacking at 1.9 nm, which might be the microporous apertures formed by the SiO2 spheres dispersed around the catalyst. As can be seen from Table 3.4, the specific surface area of the samples firstly increased and then decreased with the increase of the pyrolysis temperature. The average pore size of the CS-X catalysts was located from 4.1 to 9.9 nm. There are two main reasons for the inconsistency with the results of the pore size distribution in Fig. 3.6-b. Firstly, the stacking of catalyst particles also created some spaces that will lead to an increase in the average pore size; Secondly, the average pore size was calculated from the specific surface area and pore volume data, assuming that the pore channels were cylindrical. If the sample pore is not a regular cylindrical pore, the data will be a little deviation as shown in Fig. 3.6 that is obtained from the adsorption diagram. Fig. 3.7 shows the XRD results of the CS-X catalysts. It can be seen that cobalt species existed in the form of oxides within the catalysts, which is consistent with the HRTEM results. According to the Scherrer equation, the cobalt particle size was calculated and the specific results are listed in Table 3.4. To investigate the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the particle size of CS-X catalysts, SEM characterization was applied. As can be seen from Fig. 3.8 , an increase of pyrolysis temperature led to a gradual reduction in the particle size of the CS-X catalysts from 0.54 μm to 0.23 μm. The TEM characterization results of the CS-X catalysts are shown in Fig. 3.9 . Apparently, cobalt size increased from 8.3 nm to 13.2 nm and the cobalt species changed from CoO species to Co3O4 species with the increase of pyrolysis temperature. To investigate the number of active sites of CS-X catalysts, H2-TPD test was carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 3.10 and Table 3.5 . The results of the H2 -TPD fitting show that all CS-X catalysts existed three adsorption strengths of hydrogen. Specifically, desorption temperatures under 153 °C corresponded to weak hydrogen interactions, temperatures between 220 and 246 °C denoted moderate interactions and desorption temperatures above 400 °C were indicative of strong hydrogen interactions. Further calculation of the desorption amounts of weakly and moderately interacting adsorbed hydrogen shows that the hydrogen adsorption amount of CS-X catalysts increased and then decreased with the increase of pyrolysis temperature, which indicates that the number of cobalt active sites increased and then decreased. 3.4 FTS performance of Co@SiO2-X catalyst To further investigate the effect of pyrolysis temperature on catalytic activity, FTS evaluation was conducted. The specific reaction results are shown in Fig. 3.11 and Table 3.6 . It can be seen from the reaction results that the FTS activity of the CS-X catalysts increased and then decreased by changing the pyrolysis temperature. Among the CS-X catalysts, CS-500 and CS-600 catalysts had high dispersibility and good number of cobalt active sites due to the complete and good core-shell structure, thus showing high CO conversion rate of 63.6 % and 77.2 % respectively. Compared to CS-500 and CS-600 catalysts, CS-400 and CS-700 catalysts were less dispersed and had a much smaller number of cobalt active sites, resulting in lower CO conversions of 26.8 % and 32.8 % respectively. Further analysis was conducted on the specific C5+ product distribution of CS-X catalysts, and the results are shown in Table 3.6. Combined with the TEM images (Fig. 3.9), it can be seen that the SiO2 distribution in the shell layer of CS-400 and CS-700 catalysts was relatively loose and the spatial restriction ability of mesoporous pores in the mass transfer process was weakened, which is helpful for chain growth and makes the selectivity of C12+ increased. Comparatively, the SiO2 distribution in the shell layer of CS-500 and CS-600 catalysts was relatively tight. The synergistic effect of the hydrophobic pores of carbon modification in restricting the diffusion efficiency of the products and spatial restriction of the mass transfer process resulted in good C5∼C11 selectivity. Further improvements in CO conversion and gasoline fraction selectivity are expected by designing bi-functional catalysts for FTS process, in which one active site is responsible for C5+ synthesis while the other can act as hydrocracking of C5+ hydrocarbons. Recently, Lin et al. [46–48] prepared a series of aluminosilicate zeolites and silicate zeolites with excellent thermal and hydrothermal stability, which can maintain stability at temperatures of at least 1000 °C. Its specific surface area is 1000 m2/g or more. Especially, the Al acidic active sites possessed by aluminosilicate zeolites are a key factor that has a certain impact on the distribution of FTS products. Combined this with our findings in this work, it is a good idea to use this kind of molecular sieve with acid sites and extra-large pores as the shell layer of the catalyst to replace SiO2 shell. By further regulating the acidic sites and pore size of the zeolite, it is expected to modulating the product distribution and optimizing C5∼C11 selectivity. 4 Conclusions A series of CS-T and CS-X catalysts with core-shell structures were successfully prepared by hydrothermal synthesis method. By increasing the hydrothermal temperature, the CS-T catalysts gradually formed regular spherical cobalt cores, and the dispersion of cobalt particles increased. Among them, the CS-180 catalyst exhibited the highest CO conversion of 77.2 %. When the hydrothermal temperature was increased to 200 °C, the complexation ability of spherical cobalt nuclei to Si-OH groups adsorbed by CTA+ micelles was reduced and the excess Si-OH groups formed SiO2 spheres dispersed around the catalyst that decreased FTS activity. The FTS activity of CS-T catalysts with hydrothermal temperature showed a volcano type. By increasing the pyrolysis temperature, the particle size of CS-X catalysts became smaller and the average pore size decreased. The FTS activity of CS-T catalysts with pyrolysis temperature presented a volcano shape. Among them, the CS-500 and CS-600 catalysts showed high selectivity for gasoline section, being 62.5 % and 78.4 % respectively. coredata.dc:description: Energy is of great importance for the development of modern society, which is mostly dependent on crude oil. Due to the severe pollution caused by using crude oil and the diminishing of crude oil reserves, it is urgent to look for clean oil from alternative resource other than crude oil. Currently, Coal-to-Liquid (CTL) or Biomass-to-Liquid (BTL) technology is an important way to produce clean liquid fuels through Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) of syngas. For FTS process, catalyst is a main factor for affecting on syngas conversion and product distribution. For traditional oxides-supported catalysts, the mutual constraint between active metal loading and dispersion at high metal loading is hard to overcome, which will hinder the synthesis of high-performance FTS catalysts. In this paper, a new type of Co@SiO2-T (CS-T) and Co@SiO2-X (CS-X) catalysts with core-shell structure were prepared by using polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) as the structural stabilizer, hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium Bromide (CTAB) as the templating agent and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as the silica source. The effects of hydrothermal temperature and pyrolysis temperature on the catalyst physical-chemical properties and FTS performance were investigated. The results showed that increasing the hydrothermal temperature favored the formation of the core-shell structure of the catalysts. With the increase of pyrolysis temperature, the catalyst particle size decreased from 0.54 μm to 0.23 μm. The FTS activities of the catalysts showed a volcano trend with hydrothermal and pyrolysis temperatures.
